metadata.case_name: Indo-China Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. v. Additional Collector of Customs

facts.text: Appellant Indo-China Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. owns fleet of ships, carries goods and passengers by sea for over 80 years, plies Calcutta-Japan-Calcutta route.

Motor vessel Eastern Saga: 6,631 gross registered tons, 4,441 net registered tons, length 475-2-1/2 ft, breadth 59-3 ft, summer draft 24-7 ft, crew 14 officers and 56 seamen, 119 separate rooms including crew cabins, passenger cabins, messes, offices, insulated domestic refrigeration compartments, crew accommodation insulated with fire board panelling on wooden frames creating hollow spaces.
Eastern Saga arrived at Calcutta from Far East on October 29, 1957, carrying legitimate cargo of 24,815 packages general merchandise weighing 1,506 tons.
Vessel rummaged by Calcutta Customs Officers on October 30, 31, and November 12, 1957.

In domestic refrigeration compartments handling room: two-tier white painted shelf fixed to insulated wall, screws hammered flat, held by wooden plugs hidden under paint; below shelf, hole 7x4-1/2 inches in panelling to insulation space, closed with plug; nothing found.
Forecastle cabin: two rectangular openings in cabin wall panelling behind steel clothes locker screwed to wall, 5x13 and 5x5 inches, one closed with wooden cover; nothing found.
Compradoree's cabin: behind wooden bench screwed to wall panelling, two rectangular holes 5x4-1/2 and 8x2-1/2 inches, covered with wooden plugs and overpainted; nothing found.
No. 1 Fitter's cabin: two rectangular holes in visible wall panelling, filled and overpainted, 7-1/2x10-1/2 and 12x12 inches; nothing found.

Sailors accommodation: hole 2-1/2x5-1/2 inches in wall panelling behind back batten of wooden seat screwed to wall, covered with wood and overpainted; opened to space containing large quantity of gold bars (1,358 bars).
Further in sailors accommodation: hole behind steel clothes locker, closed with wooden plug; nothing found.

Notices to show cause issued November 12, 1957 to owners' agents (Jardine Henderson & Co. Ltd.), master (Captain Kiunear), and Kwok Cho (crew member who claimed gold), why vessel not confiscated under s.167(12A) for contravening s.52A, and penalties on agents/master.
Further notice November 13, 1957 to master re another hole discovered.

Replies by agents and master: no knowledge of gold or holes, took reasonable precautions per company instructions, report by Norman Stewart & Co. surveyors that special searches needed to find such places, Kwok Cho's statement shows smuggling without knowledge, instructions to crew against offences.

Additional Collector of Customs heard parties, order November 23, 1957: preventive measures inadequate; not concerned in illegal importation under s.167(8); No.1 Fitter cabin openings not attract s.167(12A); vessel liable to confiscation under s.167(12A) for s.52A contravention; confiscated 1,358 gold bars under s.167(8) r/w s.23A FERA (value Rs.23,79,490); penalty Rs.10,000 on Kwok Cho; confiscate Eastern Saga or fine Rs.25 lakhs within 30 days.
Appeal to Central Board of Revenue dismissed May 12, 1959: offence proved, fine not excessive, value of ship > Rs.25 lakhs.
Revision to Government of India dismissed December 17/20, 1960.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court; also Writ Petition No.138/1961 under Art.32.

legal_issues.text: Whether Central Board of Revenue (appellate under s.190) and Central Government (revisional under s.191) Sea Customs Act are 'tribunals' under Art.136(1) Constitution for special leave jurisdiction.

True scope and effect of s.52A Sea Customs Act: does contravention require mens rea/knowledge of owners/master; whether alterations in panelling constitute 'construction, adaptation, alteration or fitting' of the 'vessel' for concealing goods.
Whether liability under s.167(12A) mandatory confiscation or discretionary; quantum of fine Rs.25 lakhs excessive.
Whether s.52A read without mens rea violates Arts.14,19(1)(f),31(1) Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Customs Authorities (Collector, CBR, CG) not courts/tribunals under Art.136; revoke special leave.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.136 Constitution; precedents: Maqbool Hussain v. State of Bombay; Thomas Dana v. State of Punjab

petitioner_arguments.text: s.52A requires mens rea; no knowledge of owners/master/agents of holes/gold; precautions taken; smuggling by crew without knowledge.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.52A Sea Customs Act; criminal jurisprudence principle mens rea essential unless excluded (Ravula Hariprasada Rao v. State; Brend v. Wood)

petitioner_arguments.text: Holes in removable panelling/lining not alteration of 'vessel' (integral part); panelling for insulation/health/comfort, not shown in official plans.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.52A, s.3(f) Sea Customs Act; certificate of B. Hill Lloyds Surveyor

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if contravention, discretion to not confiscate if trivial/extenuating; fine Rs.25 lakhs excessive/vindictive, affects trade.
s.52A without mens rea ultra vires Arts.14,19(1)(f),31(1).

respondent_arguments.text: Customs Authorities not tribunals; special leave incompetent.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.136 Constitution; precedents: Shewpujanrai v. Collector; Thomas Dana; Maqbool Hussain

respondent_arguments.text: s.52A absolute prohibition, no mens rea required; vessel itself liable if constructed/adapted/altered/fitted for concealing goods; multiple suspicious holes, gold found prove purpose.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.52A, s.167(12A) Sea Customs Act; absence of 'knowingly/wilfully' unlike other clauses

respondent_arguments.text: Panelling part of vessel; holes alterations for concealment.
Mandatory confiscation under s.167(12A), but option fine under s.183; fine appropriate given gold value Rs.23 lakhs, multiple cavities, ship value higher.

court_reasoning.text: CBR (appellate s.188/190) and CG (revisional s.191) are tribunals under Art.136: quasi-judicial, trappings of court, invested with State's judicial power, hear disputes per natural justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of Act: hierarchy, appeals/revisions on merits, evidence; precedents Harinagar Sugar Mills, Shivji Nathubhai.

court_reasoning.text: s.52A absolute: prohibits vessel constructed/adapted/altered/fitted for concealing goods entering ports; no mens rea required (deliberate omission unlike other s.167 clauses); purpose to curb smuggling, proof of alteration for concealment sufficient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mens rea hard to prove for owners/master; would render section nugatory; vessel itself liable.

court_reasoning.text: Panelling integral part of vessel per s.3(f); holes constitute alteration, no functional purpose, designed for concealment (gold found).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Hill certificate irrelevant/un-tested; once constructed, part of vessel.

court_reasoning.text: s.167(12A) mandates confiscation of vessel and penalty on master; no discretion to refuse; but s.183 requires option to pay fine in lieu, where discretion on quantum considering circumstances.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Confiscation statutory corollary, fine option tempers hardship.

court_reasoning.text: Fine Rs.25 lakhs not excessive: gold value Rs.23 lakhs, multiple holes, preventive measures inadequate; deterrent needed for smuggling.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellate/revisional authorities affirmed; no interference under Art.136.

court_reasoning.text: Art.19 not applicable to foreign company; cannot challenge via Arts.14/31(1).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No opinion on citizen's Art.19 challenge.

holdings.text: CBR and CG are tribunals under Art.136.
s.52A imposes absolute liability on vessel for alterations etc. for concealing goods; no mens rea required.
Holes in panelling are alterations of vessel attracting s.52A.
Confiscation under s.167(12A) mandatory, but fine option under s.183 discretionary; Rs.25 lakhs fine upheld.
No need to decide constitutional challenge as foreign company ineligible for Art.19.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shewpujanrai Indrasanarai Ltd. v. Collector of Customs
precedents_cited.relevance: Customs order quasi-judicial, certiorari lies under Art.226.

precedents_cited.case_name: F. N. Roy v. Collector of Customs, Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Collector acts judicially under Sea Customs Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lea Roy Frey v. Superintendent, District Jail, Amritsar
Thomas Dana v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Customs officers not courts though act judicially.

precedents_cited.case_name: Maqbool Hussain v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Confiscation proceedings not judicial prosecution under Art.20(2).

precedents_cited.case_name: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sunder Jhunjhunwala
precedents_cited.relevance: CG under Companies Act s.111(3) is tribunal under Art.136.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shivji Nathubhai v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: CG review under Mineral Concession Rules judicial.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jaswant Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Lakshmi Chand
Engineering Mazdoor Sabha v. Hind Cycles Ltd.

statutes_cited.name: Sea Customs Act, 1878
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits vessels adapted for concealing goods; confiscation/penalty; appeals/revisions quasi-judicial; search powers.

statutes_cited.name: Foreign Exchange Regulation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Confiscation of smuggled gold read with s.167(8) Sea Customs Act.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction; fundamental rights; no protection for foreigners under Art.19.

outcome.summary: Appeal against orders of confiscation/fine on vessel Eastern Saga for s.52A contravention dismissed; preliminary objection overruled; Writ Petition No.138/1961 also dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "No vessel constructed, adapted, altered, or fitted for the purpose of concealing goods shall enter, or be within the limits of any port in India, or the Indian customs waters."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of s.52A, basis of absolute prohibition.

key_quotes.text: The knowledge of the owners, or even of the master is, in the context of s.52A, entirely irrelevant. What is relevant is the proof of the fact that the vessel answering the description prescribed by s.52A entered within the limits of Calcutta.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Confiscation of the vessel is the immediate statutory consequence of the finding that an offence under clause 12A is established.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Unless a statute creating an offence... rules out mens rea... no person should be found guilty... unless he has got a guilty mind.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Acknowledges principle but holds excluded by implication.
